content.title: ARR Performance Post - DD RCA on Product Issues
content.visibleText:
ARR Performance Post - DD RCA on Product Issues

The total ARR loss associated with product issues adds up to $1M.

1. Delays in handling legacy backlog ($578K ARR impact)

The focus during the first quarter was to complete the import and reduce the backlog. The decision was to not import the maintenance backlog and instead work on the backlog that had been identified as some of the ongoing issues were high severity ones and led to customer backfire.

Examples:

- AWS Case: AWS, the largest single customer loss ($700K), cited a maintenance issue that was identified before the acquisition. The issue was raised in Nov 2021 and was not resolved even after completing the import & cost reduction.
- There was another service issue that was incompletely fixed by the engineering team. There was set of already paid for but not delivered work (features) that were Engineering
- LinkedIn app was not working for more than a year due to outdated API. The import was completed by Jan 17 for PostBeyond and Jan 19 for LinkedIn.

Immediate Next Steps:

- Continue working through the maintenance backlog; estimating the impact of not doing so.

Process Improvements:

- All outstanding issues MUST be reviewed by BU/TPM/Eng and added to the internal bug ticketing system, along with any promised dates that are missed.
- All bug fixes implemented by the legacy team post acquisition MUST be reviewed as we cannot blindly rely on legacy team’s deliveries.
- Start the maintenance review work in the first quarter and factor this into the planning.
- We should combine maintenance and start teams until we reduce the backlog to manageable levels.

- If there is low to no focus on bugs - this will limit vast sprints.
- If there are plenty of bugs - this will help reducing the backlog to sensible levels.
- We need to define acceptable backlog by SE7 - what we need to get to until we decide product is “stable” - e.g. 20 bugs opened per SE7

content.title: ARR Performance Post - DD RCA on Product Issues
content.visibleText:
ARR Performance Post - DD RCA on Product Issues

The total ARR loss associated with product issues adds up to $1M.

1. Delays in handling legacy backlog ($578K ARR impact)
The focus during the first quarter was to complete the import and reduce the backlog. The decision was to not import the maintenance backlog and instead work on the high severity ones. Examples include:
- AWS Case: AWS, the largest single customer loss ($700k), cited a bug identified before the acquisition. The issue was raised in Nov 2020 and was resolved after completing the import & cost reduction.
- There was another sev1 issue that was incompletely fixed by the engineering team.
- LinkedIn app was not working for more than a year due to outdated APIs.
- The import was completed by Jan 17 for PostBeyond and Jan 19 for the overall project.

Immediate Next Steps:
- Continue working through the maintenance backlog; estimating the impact on ARR.

Process Improvements:
- All outstanding issues MUST be reviewed by BU/TPM/Eng and added to the internal bug ticketing system, along with any promised dates that were missed by the legacy team post acquisition M&A.
- All bug fixes implemented by the legacy team must be validated by the current team.
- Start the maintenance backlog earlier and factor this into the project's timeline.
- We should combine maintenance and start teams until we reduce the backlog to sensible levels.
 - If there is low to no focus on bugs - this will help with speeding up the resolution.
 - If there are plenty of bugs - this will help reducing the backlog to sensible levels.
 - We need to define acceptable backlog by SE7 - what specs we need to until we decide product is 'stable' - e.g. 20 bugs opened per SE7.

content.title: ARR Performance Post - DD RCA on Product Issues
content.visibleText:
ARR Performance Post - DD RCA on Product Issues

The total ARR loss associated with product issues adds up to $1M.

1. Delays in handling legacy backlog ($578K ARR impact)

The focus during the first quarter was to complete the import and reduce the backlog. The decision was to not import the maintenance backlog and instead work on the high severity ones. This backfired as some of the ongoing issues were high severity ones and led to a significant ARR impact.

Examples:

AWS Case: AWS, the largest single customer loss ($700k), cited a problem that was identified before the acquisition. The issue was raised in Nov 2021 and was resolved after completing the import & cost reduction.

There was another sev1 issue that was incompletely fixed by the engineering team. There was set of already paid for but not delivered work (features) that were Engineering's responsibility.

LinkedIn app was not working for more than a year due to outdated APIs. The import was completed by Jan 17 for PostBeyond and Jan 19 for LinkedIn.

Immediate Next Steps:

Continue working through the maintenance backlog; estimating the impact.

Process Improvements:

All outstanding issues MUST be reviewed by BU/TPM/Eng and added to the internal bug ticketing system, along with any promised dates that are missed by the legacy team post acquisition M&A.

All bug fixes implemented by the team are final and cannot blindly rely on legacy team's deliveries.

Start the maintenance backlog import this quarter.

We should combine maintenance and start teams until we reduce the backlog to sensible levels.

If there is low to no focus on bugs - this will help with reducing the backlog to sensible levels.

If there are plenty of bugs - this will help reduce the backlog to sensible levels.

We need to define acceptable backlog by SEP 7 - what the next goal is until we decide project is 'stable' - e.g. 20 bugs opened per SEP 7.

3. Outages or defects (346K ARR impact)

4. Migration to Elevate (> $90K ARR impact)

5. Product components not imported correctly.
